review_title: Great faculty and students, terrible administration
pros: Faculty and students are generally great, trying their best to make the most of an under-resourced university with an administration whose goals are antithetical to providing good undergraduate education and supporting research.
cons: University admin have failed at every opportunity to make decisions that would support their faculty and graduate students. On the whole, graduate students live just above the poverty line with the only true perk of attending this university being high-quality healthcare. However, university admin have explicitly stated that the healthcare (again, the ONLY benefit of working here) is, "too good for us" and is a top of the list of benefits to cut each bargaining cycle. Further, they do a lot of sending buzzword-fueled emails each women's/black/latino-a/pride month and then fail to do things to actually attract and support these communities (through PAYING them appropriately).

review_title: run far and run fast from the Hopkins-Davis lab
pros: the campus is pretty, paid vacation is decent when you're allowed to use it, if you want to feel like a token for being queer or disabled or any other minority then by all means work here its a great place for that
cons:
a wage of $16 an hour to manage a lab and create and instruct a univ course is exploitative at best, after two years was offered a raise of ~70 cents, parking cost ~$1000 a year if you want to walk a few blocks to work every day, and even more if you want to not get a $75 ticket from campus parking enforcement, who make more than most of the instructors, the ADA center is a joke and could not find me reassignment because no job without a PhD or without being some sort of a cop pays a living wage, insurance was a joke and a huge chunk of my salary as well, if your disability can't be exploited for enough profit they will fire you for it

i went through two ADA case managers in a month because the first one jumped ship entirely which should give you an outlook for employment here

I was up for reassignment after they deemed the laboratory parts of my position no longer safe to be done from home, despite having been doing them from home  for 2 years.  Further and further bottlenecks were introduced to push me out of my position.  When I inquired about the course I literally created and instructed the summer prior, I was told there were no suitable jobs found for my reassignment and terminated by the ADA Center after my boss told me he would no longer entertain "informal" accommodations.  The course is once again being taught remotely, while I am unemployed and bleeding what little money I have left.  Do not work here if you do not have an outside source of support you will not thrive or even survive.  Academia has become an absolute joke and I regret working towards a career in it over the last 18 years.  The Univ of Oregon was really the cherry on top of killing literally any interest I had left in STEM.  The discrimination is unavoidable and the privilege of the people in charge is still too blinding for them to really do anything but maintain the status quo that still benefits them.

They will treat you and talk down to you like your disability is a reason for reprimand.  Like they can somehow "manage" it out of you.

job_title: Student IT Technician in Eugene, OR
pros: Easily the best student job that I've heard of anyone having as a student, on of off campus. The boss (Sam Crow) treats you with respect and kindness, and the dynamic in the office is very chill and friendly. The whole office is very respectful of students having schoolwork as the first priority, and are great about scheduling around classes/other extracurriculars. They train you on just about anything IT-related you would want to know, and have a student meeting every week to give students a place to suggest changes/express frustration/check in. The boss is very conscious of health and the entire office is very COVID-cautious-- sending folks home when needed, and keeping employees in different rooms if working on campus. The work is interesting if you like problem-solving, and very sporadic, allowing plenty of time to work on homework/passion projects as long as you keep on top of the work when it does come up. The boss very much has our backs, as if a customer calls in and is being unreasonable/disrespectful to a student, he will have us escalate the call to him so he can take care of it in the moment, and then report it to their department head so the behavior doesn't continue. Such a great work environment, and such a great place to learn. Very chill with people of people of all races and sexualities/gender identities (that stuff just isn't really talked about, but even though I'm a woman, people don't blink an eye when I mention my girlfriend). It is a very white office, although that's mostly because we don't have a large applicant pool to draw from, and because UO is such a white school. It's also nice that the office dresses pretty casually. I'm among the few women here, but people don't mind if you wear comfy leggings/t-shirts as long as you're decent, especially as a student. Dyed hair/piercings/tattoos are also fine.
cons: There is a maximum of 25 hours worked per week which can be difficult to manage if you're trying to live on your own and pay is $12.50/hour, but those are both UO regulation, not their fault. Sometimes the work is tedious/monotonous as many customers have the same problems, but in all honesty the workload is very light, so it's a lot about having something to do in the lulls to stave off boredom. The worst day I've ever had at this job was when an already-angry customer called in and yelled at me for not being able to fix his problem on the spot (I escalated to our next level of staff, and eventually to Sam Crow, and he not only calmed down the customer but also got in direct contact with the person's supervisor to remediate the situation and told me to instantly escalate the call if he ever called in again). Bad calls are pretty rare (maybe 1-2-year), but they aren't fun to deal with when they happen.

review_title: The University of Oregon offers a comfortable place to work and the flexibility to pursue your interests.
pros:
The Division of Student Affairs allows me the opportunity to pursue new programs that are best for the students. Though each office under the umbrella of this division is unique, the leadership of many of the offices that I network with routinely is supportive of allowing members of their staff to be on the frontier of better programming.

The salary and benefits package is acceptable. With health insurance costs rising and many private companies offering high-priced, low-coverage packages, I am very satisfied with this benefit. If you were simply view my salary you would not be overly impressed. However, the cost of living here makes the salary more than adequate. The other issue with salary is that some staff members in similar positions have different pay for similar work.
cons:
Information Services is a barrier to success. Formerly Computing Services, by and large the services being provided by them are terribly sub-standard. I and many of my colleagues are forced to do without software improvements that would have increased efficiency or we must work around Information Services to obtain the software we "need" to progress. I am hopeful that a recent change in the administration will be able to focus attention on this inadequacy.

The possibility for career advancement is adequate. However, the path to advancement is not clearly defined. Senior Management does not appear to communicate the steps a staff member should take to increase their likelihood for advancement.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work, not so much anymore
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Eugene, OR
pros: Benefits are amazing, colleagues can be fantastic, flexible work schedule, fulfills a mission that is important to many. It can be fun to work for a university with such a recognized brand--everywhere I go people love the Ducks.
cons: UO was poorly managed for a very long time and now those chickens have come home to roost. For decades department heads and unit leaders were allowed to do whatever they wanted to do with little or no accountability to anyone but grant funders. Lack of coordination of resources led to rampant duplication of services, which meant spending money when it wasn't necessary and not being good stewards of public funds. And then there is the dwindling of state support: This school is so poorly funded that programs are constantly on the chopping block. Athletics is well funded but academics not--this is backwards. The current president (2017) is making a lot of changes and I don't envy the job in front of him, but these changes are gutting the soul of the university and pulling back from its public mission. The president is fixated on AAU metrics with no clear reason why--there's nothing wrong with most of those metrics, but focusing on generating PhDs regardless of demand within the individual discipline is, in the current market, unethical.

review_title: Hostile Environment for Female Employees at U of Oregon
job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in Eugene, OR
pros: This University is close to the Eugene and Springfield residential areas.
cons:
Having been an Adjunct Faculty Member at four Universities, I have to tell you that this is the only one where I experienced sexual harrassment and a hostile environment.  The Dean told me that the faculty member whom I reported for sexual harrassment was "well known for that"!  However, the administration failed to take  any action against him as I was too ill from the emotional turmoil to go before the Faculty Senate and state my case publicly.   In the eleven years that I have been in this geographic area, there have been so many cases of sexual harrassment filed against this University, many reported in the local news, that I couldn't count them.  
In addition, when I read the grading policy of the Department, I realized that the lowest grade I could give was D.  At that time, there was no F (failure) in the policy.  Amazing.  When I pointed that out to the Dean, it was finally changed to include an F.    Also, the Department Chair told me that as I had athletes in my class, I didn't have to flunk anyone!  
A terrible University, both to attend and at which to work,  in my experience.

review_title: Depends on what silo you land in. I was in Campus Operations.
pros: Great people just doing the best they can in spite of poor management making decisions about things they don't understand.
cons:
If you're in Campus Operations you can expect to receive management initiatives handed down from the top with no training or specifics. "Plan, schedule, execute... now go figure out what that means because we don't seem to know." 

They will also frequently ask you why you aren't doing what you should be doing even though they never told you what to do in the first place. Basically the managers aren't even good employees let alone good managers. This is pretty much everywhere you look.

I keep reading in the news about how the University doesn't have enough money, but we keep spending big buckets of money on stuff we don't need. Over and over. Again, management decisions. I actually heard a manager say we had to spend everything we have so the big big boss doesn't take it. Those poor students.

I guess we have a new big boss too but you wouldn't know it because we've never met the guy. Guess he can't be bothered to come and see what we actually do.

pros: If you have no other means of supporting yourself.  OK if you are not a woman and/or disabled.
cons: I was a 62 year old, female faculty member when I taught there.  Parking was so difficult for me, because I had to find an open space which had a little extra room, in order to be able to unload and assemble my electric cart which I needed to ride considerable distance into the building.  I waited 45 minutes for the space to open up and immediately pulled into it, no other waiting cars in sight.  As soon as I did,  and got out and began assembling my electric ride, a male professor DEMANDED I give him the space because otherwise he'd be late for his class.  I explained that I had been waiting 45 minutes, also had a class to teach within a few minutes, and was waiting for my handicapped plaque to be granted.  He screamed at me and went to the head of my department who told me I should have given him the parking space.  And, THAT is how the University of Oregon treats disabled, female faculty members .Ignorant administration.

review_title: Great benefits and environment, tough if you want to advance
job_title: Contracts and Operations Specialist in Eugene, OR
pros: I love working on campus, and there are wonderful resources here for our department. I also love the people on campus, and its just the right size that you can really make some strong connections with people all over the area. Its a nice community that develops. The work is interesting and fulfilling.
cons:
I joined as part of the unclassified union, which was great as an entry point, but the union makes it impossible to be promoted or advance because losing positions to classified jobs weakens their bargaining power. It seems nearly impossible for talented, qualified, experienced workers to take on more responsibility and be properly compensated. It is incredibly frustrating. 

There has also been a lot of turnover in key leaders in University administration. Almost all of the vice provosts have taken jobs elsewhere in the last few years, which has left a dearth of confidence in our leadership team as well as women and persons of diversity. That worries me.

review_title: University of Oregon is great for student workers
job_title: Student Worker and Administrative Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros:
I worked for facilities for (almost) two years. During this time, my employer was extremely understanding of my school schedule. When I was hired my manager told me "you are here for school first and this job second." 

The crew I was apart of was wonderful (not all crews are like this one). It was a great and healthy work environment. I was given many opportunities to learn new things. Overall, I could not think of a better job experience. I had a great experience while working for my crew in facilities. 

Recently there has been a change in policy that allows Student Workers to accumulate sick leave after working a certain number of hours during the week (not entirely sure of the policy). I did not have this perk for most of my employment but once I was able to use it, it was awesome. It helped out a lot during busy times of the school year like midterms and finals.
cons: Like all places of employment, there are office politics which can impact your work experience.

review_title: My work at the University of Oregon has been challenging, but at times the workload has led to burnout.
pros: The University affords you a reasonable amount of flexibility, independence, and control over the work you are assigned.  There are also opportunities to get involved in governing committees and special projects.
cons: The management style is not progressive--most managers could be describes as "transactional," but not "transformational."  It is a very conservative institution, where new ideas are driven from the top down, but rarely encouraged from the bottom-up.  Managers are more concerned with appearance than they are about doing a job right.  Salaries are below market and no raises are presently in sight.

job_title: Career Research Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros:
People are friendly and helpful
Many unionized positions
cons:
Gossip and scandal central from day one. The administration has little care for research and it shows. As the bottom rung of the research ladder, I constantly felt the pressure, especially during the formation of the union. Pre-union, I knew I would never get a raise, and many low level researchers still have incredibly bad morale. Many people are in a holding pattern, including high level tenured researchers. They drove away the two best IT guys I have ever worked with as well because they wouldn't give them full time. 

Over time, the UO came to perfectly exemplify corruption in higher level academia and the war between sometimes lazy and entitled researchers and the money hungry corporate bodies that control them while constantly patting themselves on the back. The most incompetent or outright corrupt staff and researchers are retained and transferred rather than cut all to save face and a the far off threat of a lawsuit. Boy, do I have some stories I could tell you.

review_title: A nice school for graduate work if you want a good school and still have a life.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: There is a nice balance between competitiveness and casualness.  It is not a high stress environment, but at the same time it is a respected institution.  The University seems to be dedicated to hiring professors that are both personal with the students and also following the exciting trends in research.  Eugene is a nice small city, very bike friendly, and has a wonderful climate.  The compensation, especially relative to the cost of living is very competitive.  There is a lot to do in the area, so boredom is never a problem.
cons: While it can vary wildly, it often requires a certain amount of self motivation.  It is possible to simply glide through life and you can often get by, but you don't get out of your day what you should.

review_title: Loved my unit, didn't like the bureaucratic mess everywhere else.
pros: The particular group that I worked for (CASIT) was fantastic.  My supervisors were understanding and appreciative, and people I could look at as colleagues and friends.  The benefits were also amazing; I got around a 75% discount on tuition, a sick day and vacation day for every month in the year, and good insurance.
cons: Working under the University meant that there was a lot of overhead for hiring or employment changes; payday was monthly, the hiring process often takes months (this had a much larger impact while trying to hire my replacement, even though I announced my departure date about six months prior), and your supervisor has to jump through a lot of hoops to give you a raise, even if well-deserved.  A lot of this was because of union rules, and I had them to thank for a lot of the awesome benefits, so there's that at least.

review_title: Decent employer but be vigilant to bureaucratic ups and downs
job_title: Web Services Manager in Eugene, OR
pros:
* Interesting projects to work on.
* Good benefits and decent work-life balance (depends on your unit)
* In general I would say lower stress than private sector but that might be changing as the University starts clamping down on mismanagement.
* Most of you peers, managers and clients are great to work with.
cons:
* Bureaucracy is everywhere and if you are not shielded by your manager/units you will feel the effects of it.
* You can be stuck as lone-wolf with no support and manager with zero technical background. They might be caring but they might not protect you when things go bad.
* Decentralized culture (might change in the next year) and "blame shifting" is part of the game so be vigilant and get everything in writing.

pros: Your experience will vary widely depending on which academic department you're in. But everyone is entitled to the same excellent benefits that come from having a strong union presence.
cons: The base pay is not great compared to similar AAU institutions. The administration seems to have all but declared war on the Graduate Employees and have been trying to slash their pay and benefits for a few years now. It seems like there is always some new conflict arising from the university administration's unwillingness to properly value their GEs and contingent faculty.

review_title: Good PTO and Benefits, Bad Culture
job_title: Student Records Specialist in Eugene, OR
pros: Steady income. Nice benefits. Some nice co-workers.
cons: Culture is toxic, most student record specialists are too busy being annoyed that students are causing them work to remember they are there to HELP students.  Some lead workers get away with absolutely horrendous behavior toward staff and students.  One woman regularly berates and makes staff members cry and never gets reprimanded.  Management is secretive and not interested in helping you grow or progress. The university of Oregon offers tuition discount on classes - but the registrar's office is so inflexible and not at all committed to education. They don't let their staff take advantage of this benefit.

pros: The University of Oregon is an awesome employer. I always feel welcome in my office and all of my supervisors have been open communicators who are passionate about providing a great work environment and sending their student workers on to great futures as well. There are great opportunities for advancement here.
cons: The coordination of schedules can get a little crazy in the office because we're usually coordinating student schedules as well as full time workers. Working in financial aid for a public university can be frustrating because of the limited flexibility in offering aid to students.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: Graduate teaching fellows get great medical benefits. They have state of the art facilities including excellent cafes, craft center and libraries. If you like football, there is a good community around that...if you dont like football there are a lot of other great things to do in eugene.
cons: Sometimes it feels like all of the money goes into the athletic department. I would like to see there be more diversity represented in the faculty, staff and student body.

job_title: Tutor for Student Athletes in Eugene, OR
pros:
Extremely friendly coworkers
Flexible hours
Sometimes there's time to get your own work done as well
All of the athletes I worked with were very nice and if an athlete had trouble, there was always support from advisors and fellow tutors to make sure the athlete did not slip through the cracks
cons: The building is on the far opposite side of campus from most things and there is no parking! Every time you have to pay...no employee parking is ridiculous!

review_title: Relaxing place for students to work and gain experience
pros: Its very laid back. People are great but you do have annoying grad students asking for thesis help and it is usually part of your job to help them. Benefits are great. As a student employee, work schedules are very flexible, but limited to 20 hrs. /week. Pay is better than an internship and it provided great experience and resume fodder. Note: I worked in the geography department. Other departments may differ.
cons: Sometimes its a little too laid back with no clear idea of what you should be doing. I often had big gaps between projects that I was just sitting their twiddling my thumbs.

pros: You get to make your own hours as a student which is really helpful for a class schedule and constant exams and other commitments.
cons: Your commission is based on the entire groups performance. If the group makes their goal you make more money but not everyone is committed as much as other are so it is difficult to know how much you will make on a monthly basis. A lot of the goals are unobtainable as well.

pros: The UO does offer reasonably competitive salaries and benefits - but only for unclassified Officers of Administration.  There is a tuition benefit that some employees may be able to take advantage of, but it's not as accessible as the University would like you to think.
cons:
- Classified staff have substantially lower salaries and about half the paid vacation as unclassified staff, and Analyst Programmers are classified.
- Telework is discouraged
- There's a constant churn of leadership at the highest levels
- There's almost no accountability
- In the Administration, collaboration between units is a myth

review_title: Great place for traditional academics and sports
job_title: Officer of Administration in Eugene, OR
pros: Lovely campus, great benefits for full-time employees and interesting colleagues.
cons: Focus is on 'traditional-aged' campus-based students and programs with the potential to draw them (research, STEM). Institution is somewhat hampered by retiree policies and costs, which holds more entrepreneurial departments back. Even more 'collaborative' than most of the rest of academia, things move VERY slowly, and are usually decided by top leadership. Lots of silos, though work is being done to break them down.

review_title: The most toxic environment I've ever worked in...
pros: The mascot is pretty cute.
cons:
Pretty much everything. This place is full of unethical, nasty, backstabbing people. Those co-workers that are an exception to that rule basically try to keep their heads down and stay out of the fray for fear of how they'll be impacted. Administrators talk a great game and do absolutely nothing except protect themselves and their own interests. 

Without exaggeration almost everything I was told about how my position would be structured and how things operated at the interview was a lie. 

I was a part of several hiring practices that were wholly unethical -- candidate scores changed to match a manager's personal preferences, certain applicants being given information prior to interviews that others were not given so they would perform better, amongst other things. Upon reporting these to HR, nothing was done.

pros: High volume of customers which built a lot of experience in the customer service field. They let new hires learn a vast array of services. I worked the coffee station, sandwich station, fry cook, and dishwasher. Even though they aren't a lot on their own, I can apply to a coffee shop and be just as confident as if I was applying to be a cook. They have to abide by your class schedule as a student.
cons: In the dining services department there is not a lot of room to move up. Many of the management positions are constantly shifted around and there can be a dramatic shift in the way the system works because of this.

review_title: Low paying student job, friendly coworkers and managers, difficult clientele, working for the Financial Aid Office
job_title: Information Officer At Financial Aid and Scholarships Office in Eugene, OR
pros: The job is relatively simple, somewhat like call center work. It is also seasonal, so they usually hire on in the summer when things are really busy. Once you learn the ropes, the office is rather helpful in ensuring you've got your feet on the ground before you're entrusted with too much responsibility.
cons: The pay is rather low, and often you are dealing with very angry, anxious and aggravated sorts of people. The key is to be patient, and hopefully this job is some sort of supplemental income to your student life.

pros: Free food, free housing, relatively easy job. Not really that much work, only about 10 hours a week.
cons: Some nights are really long but luckily most nights are really easy and you only have to work about 1 night a week plus 2 weekends a term. Some bosses are really good, some are the absolute worst. Sadly, the bad ones really overshadow the good ones. Also, the director doesn't have a clue to what is going on for RA's with his policies.

review_title: Your employers will underutilize you, but they won't overwork you.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: Almost all employees are unionized here, so they are protected against overwork and other common university scenarios. Additionally, the GTF health insurance is amazing.
cons: I worked for some very nice professors, and was underutilized in almost every class. Professors forget that their graduate teaching assistants didn't just spontaneously appear in graduate school, that they had formative working experience beforehand. I have been teaching for longer than most of the professors I worked for, but had no control over how I taught my course content.

job_title: Assistant to SAIL Director in Eugene, OR
pros:
All student jobs at the University of Oregon start at $10/ hr; however, after every performance review (I've had two in four years), I was given a raise of $1/ hr. I now make $12 with the SAIL program, located in the Department of Economics.
My boss is a wonderful person, who cares about individuals and her program, deeply. I went through the SAIL program, and then worked for it during my four years in college, and it's been fabulous.
cons:
No real complaints. I try to exceed my boss' expectations, and apparently succeed to some degree. 
This position is mainly office work 90% of the year, so if you don't like office tasks, don't apply.

review_title: Great environment...but you pay for it.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: Atmosphere and environment. The location is great. Eugene is the best place I have ever lived, and especially the east side of the city where the university is. It has everything you can want in a medium size town. The university tries to be a part of that.
cons: For a great atmosphere, they can afford not to pay their employees as well as other places. My bosses even mention this as "part of your salary is the trees." Meaning they know they can pay you less because everyone wants to live there.

review_title: Physics Grad Student at the UO
job_title: Graduate Research Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: Excellent work culture, laboratory facilities, instruction, and health care.  Unionized work.  I also love the Eugene area and larger Oregon area with ample outdoor recreation and food.
cons: For the most part I have no complaints about working at the UO.  I do feel that the administration and the union leadership are overly antagonistic with each other, too concerned with setting precedent and, on the university side, protecting its 'brand'.

review_title: Disrespectful faculty, low wages but GREAT benefits, and exceptional job security.
pros: The benefit package cannot be beat. Great health care for employee and family. As a union shop, there is very strong job security. I would take some real effort to get fired.
cons: The wages are incredibly low. The faculty act superior to the support staff. As a union shop, where it's nearly impossible to get fired, there is a lot of dead weight.

pros: I love the people I work with. Also enjoy how my work hours are dictated by my school schedule. The work is very easy and there is support staff to always help you.
cons: Not much room for advancement. Also, student workers get paid minimum wage until after one year where they qualify for a 3 percent raise. The pay is not that great for the amount of work being done.

review_title: Best thing to happen to me at UO
pros: I learned great personal and communication skills.  I improved my confidence and have had many opportunities because of this role. I was also able to develop leadership skills.
cons: The office was a little boring, but the supervisors made it fun by providing incentives and decorating it.  It was nice being friends with your coworkers, but sometimes that caused it to be cliquey and there was drama.

pros:
People are great to work with
Hours are great for student -- they work around your classes, tests and any conflicts you may encounter
Student work is engaging, skill based and interesting. They actually treat you like a person with ideas rather than a mindless task doer.
cons:
They are so disorganized in their administrative structure. There are too many people doing one job and not enough doing another. 
No one truly knows who to report to or who needs to sign off on a project.

review_title: The UO Knight Library does their students justice in finding them student jobs, then supporting their growth in that job
pros: I worked as an archivist, and the freedom to choose my hours and work independently was incredible. I arrived when I wanted to, listened to audiobooks while I worked, and got an astounding amount done because I was supported to do things my own way. Honesty, hard work, and openness were rewarded.
cons: There was never a dedicated space to put my project, so I was often shuffled office to office. However, lack of space is something even tenured professors deal with, so I didn't find it unfair.

pros: Probably the best large employer in the Eugene area in terms of work environment and benefits. Great campus. Mostly decent people. Lots of University events and activities to get involved with if you want. Typical large university work environment which can be very good for stability, but slow for career growth.
cons: There are many multiple IT support departments and groups that end up competing for a small pot of budget. IT as a whole is currently woefully under budgeted. University also going through MAJOR changes with the shift to more private approach.

pros:
Very Flexible in regards to classes/studying/finals
fun work environment
Great people to be around. 
great culture
various different roles so you can find what you like or do a little bit of everything
cons:
decent wage but not amazing
dont give raises but faster than minimum wage. (by the end of my time working as a facility manager I was making just a few cents more than the new hires because minimum wage had gone up so much (I worked 3 years)

pros: I was a graduate teaching fellow so there were a lot of in-tangible benefits like health insurance, free tuition (for my status), and a stipend.  My co-workers and supervisors were awesome and there was a good balance of work and school.  This was a great experience to have during my second and final year of grad school.
cons: GTF positions are inconsistent across the university and individual departments.  There is also a limited number of positions available which makes them very competitive (not that competition is bad, but it can affect whether or not a qualified candidate attends grad school).

review_title: Worked in retail dining as an undergrad.
pros: It's a pretty tight nit group of full-timers and students working in retail dining. As a student, management really tries hard to work around your school schedule and I've never had any scheduling problems here.  Very good part time job, and a free meal every shift!
cons: Job can get monotonous after being there a few years.  The pay is not very ideal, pretty much what you would expect in retail dining but without tips.

pros: Working on campus as a student was a great experience due to the ease of scheduling. I could always schedule my hours to work around my classes which took away a lot of stress. I also feel privileged to have a job as as graphic artist while in school.
cons: Sometimes the load of school work became rather heavy which made the balance of work and school a bit more stressful.

pros:
You can easily get extremely valuable experience from one of student research jobs or internships that will help your career in the future.
Very friendly staff, easy to get someone to talk to you if you have questions or concerns
cons: For the most part most student worker wages could be higher, especially given the fact that you might at times find yourself balancing you school and work assignments.

review_title: One bad apple doesn't spoil the whole bunch.
job_title: American English Institute in Eugene, OR
pros: Beautiful, environmentally-friendly campus.  Educated, diverse population - collaboration between students and staff.  Wide range of extracurricular activities and events available for staff.   Non-smoking, bike paths, and free LTD bus rides for students and staff.
cons: There is an on-going problem with bully bosses.  Classified staff aren't always treated respectfully or professionally by Unclassified staff.  Parking is expensive.

review_title: I hope the new president fixes things
pros: Eugene, OR.  Beautiful campus.
cons: Not compensated well for the stress, time/effort and education level.

review_title: GEO Study Abroad - Good for students and travel buffs
job_title: Social Media Coordinator, Study Abroad Programs in Eugene, OR
pros: Great work environment, friendly people, travel opportunities for those employed above entry level positions, UO campus location is great for sports fans and students
cons: Older employees can be patronizing to younger (especially student) employees, bosses can be a little bit uptight about projects that are fairly unimportant. Often treat student workers as workers first and students second.

job_title: Food Service Worker in Eugene, OR
pros: It was a great first time job and I learned how to use various cooking methods and devices while working at Dux Bistro. I gained experience that has scene been useful in getting me interviews. They were also very understanding when most of their student workers had bad reactions to the meningitis B vaccine that many students got on the same 3 days in early spring. They were understaffed but encouraged effected student to go home and rest.
cons: The electronic sign in pad often had problems and I often had to work late during the last shift.

job_title: Student Administrative Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros:
- My boss works around my class schedule, allowing me time to study and live my life beyond the classroom and office.
- The staff is incredibly friendly and invested in the futures of their employees.
- Guaranteed to have weekends off as well as any holiday observed by the University of Oregon.
cons: - May require working during periods of time where students are not present on campus, including summer, winter, and fall

review_title: Most of the good things I have the graduate student union to thank for
pros: Amazing healthcare, good community with other GEs, better pay than some graduate programs
cons: Overly business-minded president who prefers to punish struggling departments rather than help them, employee rights are a constant struggle, tuition is increasing, not inclusive enough to minorities (while touting inclusivity), admin culture is too corporate to make any progressive changes right now.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: I worked as an assistant at the University of Oregon for several years.  The management and admin was incredibly efficient, hard-working, and fair--I couldn't have asked for a better first job to set my bar for office relations and humane treatment of student interns.  The environment was friendly, more responsibility was given when earned
cons: I can't think of any serious cons.  But there was a large discrepancy between professors as far as the above--tasks mediated by competent management ran far smoother than if overseen by professors whose heads were often elsewhere.

pros: Broad number of professional opportunities and activities.  Undergrads who are smart and work hard can do well.
cons: Very low expectation of instructional quality.  Undergrads who do not come in privileged or driven will get swept away.  Chinese students with terrible english skills are imported, sent to a remedial program that hardly helps them learn then dumps them into classes where their only hope to pass is to cheat.  Faculty pay is low.

review_title: Great part-time Gig for a college Student
job_title: Rec Center Staff in Eugene, OR
pros: The staff is great. A position at the rec center is a desirable position for a student so most are pretty excited to work there. The hours are scheduled to accommodate class schedules and are very flexible. The new facility is coming soon which will also be a huge benefit to the University.
cons: There are a lot of employees working at the rec, so there aren't always as many hours available as one would like. There are also a lot of redundant training sessions that can be an invoninience.

review_title: Good place to work part-time as a student
pros: Supervisors were very friendly and supportive and allowed relatively autonomous work. The university pays by direct deposit, which is very convenient and easy to set up. Good work was generally appreciated by supervisory staff.
cons: There was a lot of bureaucracy to wade through. Rules were not always enforced for other employees, and supervisor/employee communication of expectations was poor at times. The work environment is fairly unprofessional. The university only pays once a month. Pay for a graduate student with prior tutoring experience is relatively low.

job_title: Student Worker, Administrative Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: As a student working for the university over the course of my studies, I appreciated the flexibility of my employers, as well as the exposure I got to the inner workings of a bureaucracy.
cons: The pay was minimal for my position, the hours were limited based on the number of students all hired to sit at a desk, and the position itself held no bearing on my projected career.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: Good pay, flexibility of schedule, challenging tasks, opportunity to learn new skills, tuition stipend.  All in all, graduate school with a teaching or research assistantship is a great deal.  I would highly advise it.
cons: I really have not had any complaints.  The professors I work with have been professional and helpful in all regards.  I've heard some students complain about teaching workloads, but I myself have been able to stick to the appointed schedule without issue.

pros: Ability to gain experience not available at other universities, Work with rare materials, and gain training in valuable areas related to safety and job growth.
cons: The behind the scenes politics can be frustrating at times, but the staff do a decent job at minimizing the impact on student workers. Some flexibility but depends on what area you are working in.

pros:
- excellent benefits
- well connected community
- love supporting students
- beautiful campus
- plenty of things to take advantage of: tuition benefits, rec center, craft center, guest lectures/ events
cons:
- culture really depends on department 
- have to apply for new positions as if external candidate within the university
- higher ed typically values new employees to come from other institutions which makes it difficult to advance within UO sometimes
- merit is difficult to reward

review_title: All in all, not a bad place to get a PhD
pros: health insurance, lots of facilities to use (CAMCOR) lots of opportunities to go to conferences etc
cons: pretty low salary for doing high level work, but it's pretty much the same anywhere you go

pros: It was a wonderful opportunity to interact with bright energetic students from all over the world. Many of my colleagues were interesting and stimulating.
cons: Management was not trained to operate a business unit. Morale was very low. Capable people were dismissed or relegated to less meaningful responsibilities, while poorly performing ones rose int eh organization.

review_title: Oregon Imaging Center- your site wouldn't let put it under company
job_title: Patient Access Specialist in Springfield, OR
pros: They have pretty good pay and nice benefits. It was a really good job if you like complete and utter redundancy.
cons: They will fire you for absolutely no reason at all. They will go off of what 2 people say and act like it's the gospel.

review_title: Poor facilities low pay, unless you are in athletics.
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Eugene, OR
pros: Great colleagues. Quality of life in Eugene is quite good , slow and wet in the winter but temperate and the summers are fantastic.
cons: Because the UO is one of the only employers many adjuncts are partners or spouses and are paid very poorly. Benefits are rare for adjuncts as well.

pros: Some positions offer flexible schedules which is great.  The benefits are certainly helpful with regard to health insurance.  You can have wonderfully bright colleagues to work with alongside.
cons: Very unstable funding for most departments.  Jobs and contracts are tenuous.  Many high level leadership positions are interim at this time creating a climate of unfocused leadership with little hope for change or innovation in the next year or two.  UO ranks at the bottom of the list for competitive salaries.

review_title: Being a graduate researcher and a student
job_title: Graduate Research Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros:
- Great health insurance
- Income supports OK living standard in Eugene
- Department is hiring many new young faculties each year who are making positive impact in the department's prestige.
cons: - The department is not very highly ranked. therefore it is not easy to land an academic position upon graduation.

job_title: Library Student Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: Working in the education field is amazing.  The focus of the job is to improve minds, and that is very satisfying.  Univ. of Oregon is set on a campus that feels like a forest, with a thousand trees encircled by the Willamette river.
cons: Compensation is average, all thing being equal.   The parking near campus is dreadful.   Having to ride a bike keeps you in shape, that may be negative for some folks.

pros: Great opportunities for students with dedicated staff and support. Fun environment and opportunities for advancement, along with wage increases and bonus incentives.
cons: My position was very routinized which made it difficult to maintain motivation, particularly due to the nature of my position- which was telefunding.

job_title: MAP Library Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: Great experience working in a library setting, with a variety of tasks to perform on a daily basis. You always have something to be working on, so boredom is not an issue.
cons: You receive minimum wage pay for consistent, hard work, which is not a total con, but should be considered. There are other library positions that pay the same or more, and you can study. There is no option to study during working hours at the MAP library.

job_title: Computer Based Note Taker in Eugene, OR
pros: Attending all sorts of interesting classes outside your major. Helping people in need. Great pay for a student job, starting at $11 and can increase to $16 with additional certifications.
cons: Very little flexibility. Very little oversight from management or feedback from the students you are taking notes from so there is no way to know if you are doing a good job or not.

review_title: Assisted in teaching an undergraduate physics lab
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: I had the opportunity to gain some experience and make a little bit of money on the side while I pursued my degree. It was a good chance to relearn some of the fundamentals as well. The position was secondary to my studies, and the hourly requirements were reasonable for a full-time student.
cons: Compensation is low, but I wouldn't expect an undergraduate TA to make very much anyway. It was mostly about the experience.

review_title: Rec Center - Great job as a student
pros: AWESOME supervisors, some of the actual big wigs of the place are kinda stuck up and lame, but you don't ever really have to deal with them on a regular basis.
cons: They took out our chair in the weight room, meaning during 6 hour weekend shifts we couldn't sit. That is BS, and at any other gym you go to, the fitness attendant is allowed to sit.

review_title: Working for the UO as a post-doctoral fellow
pros: the hours are flexible, my colleagues are smart and fun to work with. The work is challenging and rewarding. Eugene is a really affordable place to live, which makes a post-doc salary completely livable.
cons: Working as a post-doc (on fellowship or not) the benefits aren't that great (health insurance, but no retirement). As anyone looking for a post-doc knows, this is a temporary position with no opportunity to move up with out leaving UO.

job_title: Machine Learning Research in Eugene, OR
pros: Flexible schedule; helpful, respectful staff; interesting work to do, and interesting work being done by others. Lots of neat people.
cons: Pressure to publish was off-putting, and seemed to detract from the actual purpose of research. A bit of an ivory-tower feel - not sure what could be done about that.

pros: Extremely flexible, especially with your class schedule. Great job for any student to have while in college, especially if you start early and have the opportunity to fill a management position.
cons: Not great pay. Students get paid once a month and make minimum wage. Hard to feel valued because there are so many other employees.

review_title: Great for college... but terrible job
job_title: Rush Sales Associate in Eugene, OR
pros:
Only work for 2 weeks
Works well with class schedules
Fun people to work with at store
Learned a bit about customer service
cons: Not fair assessment in hiring full time employees versus temp. I worked for 3 years, never offered full time position.

review_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow (March 2014 - December 2014), Principle of Microeconomics, Intermediate Macroeconomics
job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: As a GTF, I access to all university facilities and enjoy low-rate comprehensive health care coverage. My department provides enough academic resources for GTFs and the working environment is cooperative and vibrant.
cons: We do not have much flexibility for sick leaves and emergency leaves, but the policy doesn't affect me personally. Also, the University didn't fully satisfy the GTF union's needs during the bargaining session.

pros: Really easy job if you know how to code basic web dev, pretty good pay for how little work you do.
cons: Absolutely no communication from management. I would come to class having no idea what I would be helping teach that day, and then we would spend most of class watching the instructor struggle through a small error in the code.

review_title: Great opportunity for students who want an on campus job
pros: My coworkers are great, the job is relaxed and easy,  and the hours are based around everyone's school schedules. All of the upper management is personable and fun to work with.
cons: It can be boring if there is no one in the labs. I spent possibly too much time watching Hulu during the slow hours of the morning or evening (depending on the shift).

pros: Great learning experience and provided me a great first job. Very flexible with class times and exams. Would recommend working at the school to any student
cons: At times you could be forced to do things outside of your position. This is not a big deal but be advised and alert about this.

review_title: Assistant Coordinator for the Chinese Flagship Program
job_title: Chinese Flagship Program Assistant Coordinator in Eugene, OR
pros: Great environment of working on campus and at the Baker Center downtown.
cons: I had to go through 3 different employers within 4 terms of working there as a GTF. I managed well, but it did make it difficult with the change in leadership.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: While being in graduate school, I have had the opportunity to work independently on research efforts, as well as in a collaborative manner with Pacific Northwest National Lab and several industry partners.
cons: I really don't have many cons to working at the university of Oregon other than the organization is fairly siloed and it can be challening to access all of the departments/programs, and pushing paperwork through can be slow.

pros: Great atmosphere, good bosses, an awesome place to have worked while in college for your post college resume, would highly recommend
cons: Some bureaucracy going on with staff members trying to boost their resumes, pay is so much worse than comprable jobs, but as a student you can't complain

job_title: Graduate Research Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: Relaxed atmosphere, are willing to work around your schedule.  Great benefits.  If you want to work with very intelligent people that share similar values, this may be a good place to choose.
cons: Reimbursements can often be a hassle.  You sometimes will spend more time dealing with these issues than you might want to.  Personal growth is limited if you are not going to get a doctorate.

pros: Great working environment, and a great part-time job. Allows for experience in advertising and sales, as well as learning client relationship-building skills.
cons: The first year is spent prospecting, which means a very low paycheck. Also a bit time-consuming of a job while taking on a full course load.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: Your expensive tuition would be waived and you could get better health insurance by enrolling in the GTFF insurance plan.
cons: Heavy work load. For some classes, you have to teach 4 labs, and grade 80 students' project in each week.

review_title: It really depends who you are working for.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: Stipend and tuition waved while going to school, limited to 20 hours a week so teaches can't over-exploit you, when there is a grader, the workload is much more manageable and fulfilling.
cons: Workload can vary immensely depending on who you work for.

pros: Steady employment for classified workers
cons: Classified union workers accept lower than market wages for having decent benefits. Recent union negotiation have eroded those benefits and reduced wages in real dollars. Benefits for part time classified workers are even lower.

review_title: Good place to gain work experience.
pros: I worked as a recycler for a year. The campus is relatively conscious of zero waste efforts and tries to be an active change agent. Pays minimum wage, but that is expected. Coworkers are friendly and management is welcoming.
cons: While management is welcoming, they also can have some leadership shortcomings. But that strictly depends on their personalities.

review_title: Need to base hiring on qualifications and not minority status
pros: Great people to work with, cooperative, helpful, desiring to have a safe work environment.
cons: Hiring practices include applicants getting "points" in his/her favor that have nothing to do with the job applying for. It is actually reverse discrimination and decisions to hire are ultimately made with items that have nothing to do with the abilities and qualifications to do the job.

pros:
Flexible hours
Easily accessible bosses 
Lots of employees willing to cover shifts when needed
Fun atmosphere and friendly coworkers 
Well organized
cons: The pay is not great and it is always really humid in the pool. We are required to attend lots of trainings that aren't always at the best times

pros:
I worked as desktop support for the Center for Media and Educational Technology in the University of Oregon Library system. It was a great first job, I can credit my career to this job. 

Good, welcoming environment, great place to get some IT support experience.
cons: Hours limited due to student status. Really the only con I can think of.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Eugene, OR
pros: The university science community is well supported. Mentorship from professors is good. Graduate student union enables fair access to good health insurance and protects the rights of the graduate students.
cons: Every couple years bargaining becomes stressful as the University tries to remove some of the hard-earned benefits won in previous bargaining sessions.

review_title: Beautiful University Setting with quick problem solving for employee issues
pros: Great peer and inter-agency networking. The university was good at listening to complaints even if they weren't always resolved.
cons: It still is a university setting so burnout does happen quickly if you do not invest in yourself. The pay is mediocre for some of the requirements they ask. Unequal hiring of the genders, but that could be lack of qualified applicants.

review_title: Fantastic leadership experience that allows you to work closely with professionals
pros: Leadership opportunities are very abundant.  Great resume builder as it demonstrates responsibility.
cons: Very time consuming and can become difficult to focus time on academic work.  There is a sense of competition to do more or be more constantly.

review_title: I had a good experience here
pros: Not so much stress, flexible working hours, working with a lot of academic guys and  a lot of amazing projects.
cons: Weather. University of Oregon is located at Eugene, OR, and it rains a lot in winter. If you are a raining lover, this probably is the ideal job for you, if you are not, consider somewhere else.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: I got lucky and had an amazing mentor, but that was the exception rather than the norm of most people's experiences working at UO. Other than that... it's a pretty campus in the spring? Okay benefits.
cons: Poor pay, no room for advancement, mostly shoddy buildings and no investment in maintenance.

review_title: Loyal, competitive wages, and great employees
job_title: MMJ Output Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: I love the culture at the U of O. Everyone at the UO PDX campus is great to work with and pleasant to be around. The smaller campus size makes it feel like a family. The pay is decent for the position I hold.
cons: Although part-time, I have not received a raise or review for a potential raise in the 2 years I've worked there.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: I have never had to work more than stated in the collective bargaining agreement, and have been able to carry out my own studies and research. Great health care coverage: virtually free for single GTFs, and very cheap (so far) for couples and families.
cons: Apparently, according to statistics, in some departments compensation (salary and health coverage) is below that of comparable institutions across the country.

pros: Great environment to work in. Co-workers are friendly, and faculty were always courteous. Enjoyed being the face of the office and being able to help out fellow students.
cons: Limited hours and a temporary position due to it being part of the university work study program. Also, the work is not always fulfilling (lots of busy work), but it made it easy to keep up on studying sometimes.

pros: A great work environment with friendly and helpful people. I was always able to find something to do or get help if I needed it. I immediately felt at home in the lab and definitely recommend it for others.
cons: Though I enjoy my time working in the University or Oregon's Labs, I would have liked to have gotten more hours, which were somewhat limited.

pros: I had a great boss I worked with. She trusted me and we got a lot done in 1.5 years of my work there. Beutiful campus and good benefits for the employee and family.
cons: Large university where you can kind of get lost and forgotten about. My department had a lot of drama and conflict going on.

review_title: Extremely disorganized, chaotic, complacent, and wasteful
pros:
* Almost impossible to get fired
* No one knows or cares how you spend your time (See above)
* Benefits are fantastic
* Work / Life is fantastic (See bullet #2 above)
cons: The entire organization is basically an ever expanding collaborative of wasteful effort that never really manages to accomplish anything beyond the marketed bs shoveled toward the general public. If any of these students really knew how their tuition dollars were being wasted they would quit coming entirely.

pros: Great job for students. Always willing and flexible with schedule changes and conflicts with school. Extremely supportive and willing to train candidates.
cons: Low pay, but for student work not too bad.

review_title: Personal Trainer at UO Rec Center
job_title: Certified Personal Trainer in Eugene, OR
pros: Great place to development skills for first time trainers. The Rec Center wants to help their employee develop skills to benefit them in the future
cons: Too autonomous, especially for new trainers. It is almost solely student run and very little oversight of the trainers occurs

pros: Very flexible hours, willing to work around classes. Great community. Easy with lots of dead time for homework.
cons: Most jobs offered are only minimum wage. Must reapply each year, so it is possible you could lose your own job to someone who has never done it.

pros: Works around class schedule, great environment, students and co-workers are a pleasure to work with. The University gives fair pay for the work expected to be done.
cons: Can only work part-time, so hours are limited because of that. Also because of part time no real benefits are ever seen, but seems fair for a student job. High taxes out of paycheck.

pros:
Great Pay and Benefits
Not very hard work, and 9-5 schedule 
Highly educated co-workers
cons:
The students you meet and develop relationships leave after 4 years (hopefully) 
They don't always hire from within
long and extensive application

review_title: Working on campus as a student is awesome
job_title: EMU Event Services in Eugene, OR
pros:
- Close to your classes
- Bosses who understand that school comes first
- great way to get engaged with campus
- meet a lot of great people, make new friends
cons:
- Hours can be rough (depends where you work on campus)
- Its a government job, so there is a lot of hierarchy regarding decision making
-

review_title: My position allows me to be versatile and engage i leadership development, programming, and large-scale event planning.
job_title: Student Director for Orientation Programs in Eugene, OR
pros: The inclusive environment and pro-student vision spreads across multiple departments of the institution.
cons: Eugene, Oregon and the University is relatively homogenous ethnically, especially when compared to other PAC-12 competitors.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: Excellent learning experience if you want to pursue a career in academia.  Very good benefits (thanks to the GTF federation!).  It helps complete your graduate school.  Can't complain at all.
cons: Depends on the GTF assignment, grading is tedious and complicated.  Many undergraduate students are not interested in attending or participating in class but they want an A.

job_title: Dining Services Student Worker in Eugene, OR
pros: Easy to get hired, flexible scheduling with your classes.
cons: Carson Dining Hall is run differently because it is buffet-style dining. The supervisors and upper-level employees encourage a stressful, fear-based work environment and don't help acclimate new student employees very well. No free meals or food included.

pros: The management in UO Housing is great and makes working in dining services a great time. The environment is relaxed, but still focused on serving customers.
cons: Schedules can be a bit hectic. There are times when a lot of coworkers will call in sick and then you'll be asked to come in. Often times, dining was either over or under staffed.

pros: A wonderful collegiate community and many loyal tenured faculty members. Of course Duck Athletics is point of pride!
cons: The weather - many gray and rainy days - if you like this type of climate - a pro for you.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros:
-being an RA is a good way to earn money while in law school
-the hours can be very flexible
-working with professors is good for a resume and may result in a publication
cons:
-the law school is not very diverse and the culture reflects it
-most law students have little spare time to begin with
-the law school now allows externship credit while being paid

pros: Friendly work environment.  Very flexible schedule and on campus. Perfect for a student's unpredictable life.  Very enjoyable being the center node for all admissions information and processes.  Main responsibilities keeping information flowing between departments.
cons: Work space open to public with history of personal items stolen. Parts of job consisted of database management, which is mind numbing.

1.Too much rain in Eugene;
2. Small town, no many things can do for fun.

review_title: Friendly and fun place to work with good experience
pros:
Strong training program.
Feels like you are part of team. 
supervisors often ask you how things are going or your opinions on issues. 
Staff is understanding and helpful when you make a mistake. (they want you to succeed).
cons: Sometimes customers can be rude or pushy, however this is not the managements fault.

review_title: The University provided a supportive work environment, particularly as a concurrent graduate student.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: Great benefits and work/life balance for employees with families.
cons: Less interaction across departments than I would prefer in the day to day experience. However, there are weekly social events sponsored by the University that attempt to bridge this divide.

pros: Everyone there is pretty nice, but at the end of the day, it's just a job. Invested in cool trainings and certifications for everyone.
cons: High expectations and demanding for very little pay. Can be annoying how bureaucratic the department is.

job_title: Accounts Payable Intern in Eugene, OR
pros: Great place for students because it's right on campus and has many internship opportunities. The staff is friendly and often are UO alumni themselves.
cons: I feel like a lot of the staff are often condescending to me because I am a student worker, although I perform many of the same tasks they do.

review_title: Great opportunity to build professional skills
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: My immediate supervisor offer me and the student team ample opportunity to learn new skills related to team and office administration and beyond.
cons: Hours and available work time is a little limited depending on your job type. Also compensation remains static, again depending on work type.

job_title: Office Specialist II in Eugene, OR
pros:
Lovely & thoughtful coworkers (again depends on your department), students are great.
Beautiful campus, benefits incredibly solid.
Good union reps, work-life balance protected by union.
cons:
Predictable, but university politics can really drag from the mission of helping students.
Salaried coworkers definitely expected to work outside of office hours
Commitment to Diversity and Inclusion (specifically retaining BIPOC staff) lacking.

job_title: Library Student Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros:
The knight library is fairly flexible with schedules because they understand that I am a student first and foremost. 
The supervisors in my department are friendly.
cons: The number of hours a student can work is limiting if you are supporting yourself. There is a 25 hour maximum for students enrolled full time.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Fellow in Eugene, OR
pros: Everyone around here is very hardworking and driven. This helps everyone around to focus on their jobs better. Overall it's an enjoyable place to work.
cons: I couldn't find any downside of this job in the last year and a half. Only thing I can complain about (and I do) is the coffee of the department.

pros: Independent work environment, opportunities for more responsibility and to learn become available quickly. Work around class scheduling and academic commitments.
cons: Pay period is monthly, which kind of sucks...and there isn't much in the way of technical training or job adjustment/training period - you just get straight to it and ask questions along the way.

pros: Worked in a team oriented environment.  Developed many skills including customer service, interpersonal skills, and communication.
cons: The only con about the job I can think of is working hours you don't want to work.  There will be some late nights.  You have to juggle school with some late hours of work.

review_title: It is a good place for research.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Eugene, OR
pros: People here are friendly and helpful. The culture is quite open and free. Work life balance is quite good. So it's a good place to go for graduate school.
cons: Focusing more on social science, so not too good for natural science and technology people. Not many choices for engineering people.

pros: Flexible Schedule, Tons of Resources Available, Up to Date Facilities, Professional Staff, Paid Training, Worker Accident Protection.
cons: Work Nights and Weekends and Decrease in Work Hours July and August.

review_title: Academic culture but increasingly corporate overseers
pros:
Real feeling of community
Feels like many small offices, not one big one
Union shop

Ever-increasing budgetary woes
Remember: the reason academic infighting is so vicious? Because the stakes are so low.

review_title: I had a great opportunity to move into some project work from my graduate studies.
job_title: Research Assistant/Teaching Assistant/Grant Writer in Eugene, OR

review_title: student assistant at University of Oregon Science Library

cons: There was turnover; and a constant challenge to find a strategic plan and mission; lacked consistent direction

pros: Beautiful campus, great union, nice place to live, rewarding work, lots of independence.

review_title:

Students

review_title: U of O - nice place to work
job_title: Director of Information Services in Eugene, OR

pros: They work with your class schedule, the managing staff is nice, you can work with your friends, low pressure work.

pros: The department that I work  in does a great job of being concerned about the employees. We genuinely feel that the department cares about employees

pros: Wonderful people to work with, flexible scheduling to allow students to take classes at times they want.
